author: ComputerWeekly.com(editor@www.com)
title: Ofcom to regulate Amazon Instant Video and Netflix
text:
Download Current Issue 
The regulation of video-on-demand (VoD) and catch-up programming services – such as those provided by Amazon Instant Video, BBC iPlayer and Netflix – is to be brought fully inside Ofcom to sit under the same umbrella as broadcast content regulation. 
The change was announced following a review conducted by the telecoms and broadcasting authority to ensure both types of content are regulated as effectively and efficiently as possible. 
During the course of the review, the regulator re-examined the co-regulatory arrangements for on-demand and catch-up TV services, which have been led by the Ofcom-designated Authority for Television On Demand (ATVOD) since 2010. 
Ofcom has now decided that due to the massive take-up of such services in the UK – a recent study conducted by the regulator showed that VoD services were watched by 57% of over 15 year-olds in the UK in 2014, compared with 27% in 2010 – it would now be more effective for it to act as sole regulator. 
Ofcom said ATVOD had played an important and effective role in regulating on-demand content and the two bodies would work closely together to transfer responsibilities in such a way that consumers remained protected from harmful content. 
ATVOD has played a significant role in regulating on-demand TV over the past five years and, similarly to Ofcom, it is committed to protecting audiences from harmful content. 
The change will take effect in January 2016. The Advertising Standards Authority will continue to act as a co-regulator for advertising content on video-on-demand services. Netflix subscribers shoot up 
Ofcom’s announcement came shortly after Netflix announced its third quarter results, showing impressive growth in subscriber numbers outside its domestic US market, backing up Ofcom’s own statistics on market growth. 
The service now boasts 69.2 million members worldwide, up from 65.6 million in the second quarter and 53.1 million this time in 2014. It added 2 million members outside the US during the quarter. 
Although revenues of $1.74bn missed analyst expectations, Netflix made international sales of $517m during the period, up $62m sequentially.  Handbook
